head.title: Confidence Intervals for the Population Mean

body.p: The purpose of this activity is to learn how to use statistical software for calculating confidence intervals for μ when σ is unknown. In this case, using software is useful in the case when all you have is the raw data, and in the case when only summary statistics are provided (more specifically, the sample mean and the sample standard deviation s). The reason for using software in the latter case is, as mentioned before, the complexity of determining the appropriate t*.

Background: As part of a large survey conducted at a large state university, a random sample of 142 students were asked: "How many hours do you sleep in a typical day?" The datafile linked below contains the data. Use these data to estimate μ, the mean number of hours college students at this university sleep in a typical day, with a 95% confidence interval.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.

Note that in this case we need to find a confidence interval for μ when σ is unknown, and we will therefore use the interval that we have just introduced ("t-interval"). To do this in Excel, we're going to use the equation

for the confidence interval. Before we can do this, we first have to calculate the values for each of the variables in the equation:

ul.li: To calculate the critical value t*, we use the Excel function T.INV.2T(probability, degrees of freedom). In this case, we would type =T.INV.2T(0.05, 141).
To calculate the sample mean, use the AVERAGE function. In this case, we would type =AVERAGE(A2:A143).
To calculate the sample standard deviation, use the STDEV function. In this case, we would type =STDEV.S(A2:A143).
To calculate the standard error, we'll divide the sample standard deviation that we just calculated by the square root of n.
Finally, we calculate the margin of error by multiplying the critical t* value by the standard error.
IMPORTANT: There is a shortcut alternative that is similar to calculating the margin of error when the population standard deviation (sigma) is known.

To calculate the margin of error using the shortcut, we use the Excel function CONFIDENCE.T(a,s,n), where a is the alpha value, s is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size. Note that the alpha value a = 1 - C, where C is the confidence level (in our case, 0.95). In this case, we enter the formula as follows: =CONFIDENCE.T(0.05, 1.5985, 142)

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To open a list with the sleep data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
The hours slept data should be stored in L1.

Note that in this case we need to find a confidence interval for μ when σ is unknown, and we will therefore use the interval that we have just introduced ("t-interval"). To do this on your TI graphing calculator:

Choose DATA by using arrows to highlight DATA, then pressing ENTER.
